document.masterDocTitle: Review of the genera Pristocera Klug and Pristepyris Kieffer (Hymenoptera Bethylidae, Pristocerinae) of Russia and adjacent territories

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Review of the genera Pristocera Klug and Pristepyris Kieffer (Hymenoptera Bethylidae, Pristocerinae) of Russia and adjacent territories

heading.emphasis:
Key to species of the genera
Pristocera
and Pristepyris European part of Russia and adjacent territories

paragraph.keyLead: - Females ( ♀ ) wingless; body mainly yellow or reddish ( Figs 1B , 3 , 4B , 6 , 7B , 8 )................................... 4

2(1). Metasomal segments entirely black or dark brown ( Fig. 7A ); hypopygium not divided into two lobes, subtriangular ( Fig. 7C ); distal part of harpe slender, slightly curved; active in July – October; body length 7.0–8.0 mm............................................................................................
Pristepyris masii ( Giordani Soika, 1933 )

- Metasomal segments I–III reddish, remainder segments brown ( Figs 1A , 2G , 4A , 5K ); hypopygium deeply divided into two lobes ( Figs 1D , 4C ); distal part of harpe wide and flattened; active from February to June, usually in spring.............. 3

3(2). Median carina of clypeus high, subtriangular in lateral view with its outer corner almost right and only apex weakly rounded; transverse pronotal carina and posterior pronotal sulcus absent ( Figs 2C, F ); dorsal pronotal area with transverse striation in narrow anterior part ( Figs 1A , 2F ); forewing hyaline, not darkened ( Figs 1A , 2K ); metapectal-propodeal disc with median carina developed posteriorly, forming narrow elongated cell ( Figs 1A , 2I ); harpelong and twice sinuate, without tooth on inner side of end; aedeagus long, conical, slender, its apical lobe long and deeply divided up to half its length; active in early spring; body length 8.0–12.0 mm.....................................................
Pristocera depressa ( Fabricius, 1804 )

- Median carina of clypeus low ( Figs 5A, C ), arched in lateral view; transverse pronotal carina and posterior pronotal sulcus well developed ( Figs 5C–E ).; dorsal pronotal area without transverse striation ( Figs 4A , 5D ); forewing faintly darkened from pterostigma to wing apex ( Figs 4A , 5M ); metapectal-propodeal disc without median carina ( Figs 4A , 5D ); parameres (harpe) short, C-shaped and with low blunt tooth on inner side of end; aedeagus short, subconical, thick, its apical lobe divided up to quarter its length, rounded; active from late spring to half of summer; body length 10.0–14.0 mm...................................................................................................
Pristocera morawitzi
sp. nov.

4(1). Median lobe of clypeus with two short projections and central notch in dorsal view ( Fig. 8A, B ); active in July–August (second half of summer); body length 4.0–6.0 mm.................................
Pristepyris masii ( Giordani Soika, 1933 )

- Median lobe of clypeus with three or four projections and without central notch in dorsal view ( Figs 3A , 6A ); active from February to July (usually in spring to first half of summer); body length 7.0–10.0 mm............................... 5
